newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Arco, Russia's Lukoil, sign deal.
newsitem.headline: Arco, Russia's Lukoil, sign deal.

text.p: Russia's largest oil producer, Lukoil, and the Atlantic Richfield Co. have signed their $5 billion joint venture agreement, Lukoil said Monday.

A statement issued by Lukoil said the companies signed the 18-year pact, which was announced last September, in Washington Friday evening. Under the deal, the two founded a joint venture, SP Lukarko, to prospect for and develop oil in the former Soviet Union.
It said Arco would extend a $4.5 billion credit line to Lukarko, total investment would be about $5 billion and 1997 investment would be about $400 million.
Arco owns 7.99 percent of Lukoil. The Russian company will have a 54 percent stake in the new joint venture and Arco will have a 46 percent stake.

Initial projects include a 12.5 percent stake in the Caspian Pipeline Consortium, a line expected to carry oil from Kazakstan to Russia's Black Sea, and a 5 percent ownership in the Tengiz oil field in Kazakstan.

Arco had previously failed to establish a strong overseas presence, according to oil industry analysts. But the deal with cash-strapped Lukoil gives the U.S. oil giant a powerful political ally in the former Soviet Union.
